name: places/ChIJ2WKYxIdZwokRHdUVxMeAAzo
formattedAddress: 115 Chrystie St, New York, NY 10002, USA
adrFormatAddress: 115 Chrystie St, New York, NY 10002-5000, USA

originalText.text:
I am frankly gobsmacked at the poor reviews this city agency has gotten!  I "lost" my Medicaid coverage 5 years ago. (If you win the Powerball lottery, depending on your situation, say good-bye to SSI, SSD, SNAP, MEDICAID and subsidized housing. Didn't know that did you?)  I digress, unable to access the HRA ACCESS app, I chose to skip Bklyn and visit the nearest Medicaid office, Chinatown, a place I had been to many years ago. All I remembered from then was a warren of crowded cubicles and offices and literally hundreds of Asians standing wall-to-wall. When the elevator door on the 5th Floor opened, I was not sure I was in the right place. Where was everybody? It was mid-afternoon on a week-day!. "Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse." (E.A. Poe)
The Info kiosk ejected a ticket with a high number (2011) and no sooner had I stepped into a large, empty waiting room, it was called right away. I was welcomed by a gentleman who asked me how he could help me. I told him I wanted to pick up an application. He asked me for ID. I gave him my NYS Driver License which, judging by his reaction, he didn't see very often. He told me, "You don't need one." How come? I asked.  Because your case is active, he said. Since when? I asked.  Since October 1st, i.e., the past two MONTHS!  I requested that in writing. He was delighted to hand me the confirmation. What started out as a simple inquiry turned out to be a fast-forwarded start-to-finish graduation. . I showed him my old Medicaid card. He said, take that card with this paper and go to any hospital. It all happened so fast!  I left the building whistling, "Everything is Tickety-boo" as sung by Danny Kaye.  On the subway ride home, I gave my seat up to a child. I am 72 and walk with a cane but felt like I was on top of the world.

(If you win the Powerball lottery, depending on your situation, say good-bye to SSI, SSD, SNAP, MEDICAID and subsidized housing. Didn't know that did you?)  I digress, unable to access the HRA ACCESS app, I chose to skip Bklyn and visit the nearest Medicaid office, Chinatown, a place I had been to many years ago. When the elevator door on the 5th Floor opened, I was not sure I was in the right place. Where was everybody? It was mid-afternoon on a week-day!. "Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse." (E.A. Poe)

I asked.  Since October 1st, i.e., the past two MONTHS!  I requested that in writing. He was delighted to hand me the confirmation. What started out as a simple inquiry turned out to be a fast-forwarded start-to-finish graduation. . I showed him my old Medicaid card. He said, take that card with this paper and go to any hospital. It all happened so fast!  I left the building whistling, "Everything is Tickety-boo" as sung by Danny Kaye.  On the subway ride home, I gave my seat up to a child. I am 72 and walk with a cane but felt like I was on top of the world.

originalText.text:
I’m glad I went against all the bad views here and took my 80yr old parents to this Medicaid office to fix their service cancellation problem. Before I share my experience, I want to say the ladies working there are very helpful if you are prepared and clearly explain your problems. They get my 5 star review. I think there are many 5-star experiences that people don’t bother to share and thank the people there.

After reading all the bad reviews, My parents and I were prepared to go there to wait and get mistreated. We got there 10 min before they opened and got the first number from the ticket kiosk. The kiosk only takes 3-clicks to get a number, but can be intimidating to seniors without help. We sat down briefly and we were called. There were 2 ladies helping people, then more ladies started to help. Our case was complicated because of an incorrect address that led to service cancellation. The lady who helped us took about 40 min to look up all the information while we waited outside. From my observation, people with simple issues were helped on average every 15mins. All the ladies were calm and helpful. The office was not crowded around Jun 2022. Finally back to our case and the lady who helped us gave us standard instructions to fill out some big forms. At first it was intimidating, but we were patient and the lady was patient to guide us. I was prepared with some of the information needed, but still missing a lot of info to complete the form…myself to blame and not the lady there. Fortunately she was able to retrieve my parents info from the system and reduced our paperwork. The paperwork took around 40mins and she spent another 10min to enter into the system. Our messy problem was resolved at 10:30am.

I was expecting the worst to spend a whole day there, but with the help of the nice lady we were done in 1hr 30min. Few things to suggest…Go there early. Have patience. Entertain yourself with the phone while waiting. Be prepared with your documentation such as IDs, proof of address, financial statements and medical papers. Clear description of the problem. Bring a translator who is very familiar with the issues…don’t assume it is in Chinatown and anyone there can help in Chinese.

originalText.text: Security was very nice and professional. Security took the wet floor sign out due to the rain. Inside the office area was clean as well as the bathroom. The women working there were kind and helpful. This location is specifically for people 65+ or individuals with disabilities.  So they couldn't help me with my issue because I am not 65+ nor have a disability. But they directed me to the Brooklyn location to resolve my issue. My overall experience was pleasant. No complaints from me. Keep up the good work everyone. Thank you for your help.

originalText.text: the security people were extremely nice. the lady in the front with blonde hair needs to change her demeanor towards Asian people. she raises her voice towards them and doesn't to people who aren't Asian. they need Asian people working there for people who can't speak English.

originalText.text: If I could give 0 stars, I would.  I’ve been waiting for more than an hour in the office for a ticket number that was next in line. For the past 30+ minutes, there have been no change in ticket number for all letters in the queue.  Looked over the stations in the room due the the incredible amount of chattering noise that generated and noticed only 1 station had actual person they were helping. The other stations were busy talking to the security guard and other colleagues rather than helping those in the waiting room. Meanwhile, the waiting room had more than 10+ people waiting to be helped. I understand this is a government agency, however, shouldn’t taking care of these people be more important than having a conversation of what your weeekend plans are?
